title-group.article-title: Management status of end-of-life vehicles and development strategies of used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China

contrib-group.aff: School of Mechanical Engineering, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, P.R. China

author-notes.corresp: Ming Chen, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, School of Mechanical Engineering, Building A, Room 815, #800 Dongchuan Road, Shanghai, 200240, P.R. China Email: mingchen@sjtu.edu.cn

article-meta.issue-title: Special issue: Waste electrical and electronic equipment

abstract.p: Recycling companies play a leading role in the system of end-of-life vehicles (ELVs) in China. Automotive manufacturers in China are rarely involved in recycling ELVs, and they seldom provide dismantling information for recycling companies. In addition, no professional shredding plant is available. The used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China has yet to take shape because of the lack of supporting technology and profitable models. Given the rapid growth of the vehicle population and electronic control units in automotives in China, the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry requires immediate development. This paper analyses the current recycling system of ELVs in China and introduces the automotive product recycling technology roadmap as well as the recycling industry development goals. The strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and challenges of the current used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China are analysed comprehensively based on the ‘strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats’ (SWOT) method. The results of the analysis indicate that this recycling industry responds well to all the factors and has good opportunities for development. Based on the analysis, new development strategies for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in accordance with the actual conditions of China are presented.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: According to statistics gathered by the China Association of Automobile Manufacturers, the vehicle market of China set a new sales record of approximately 18 264 700 in 2010, bringing the total number of vehicles in the country to 90 860 000. With the increasing vehicle sales, relevant agencies have forecasted that the volume of end-of-life vehicles (ELVs) will reach 8.31 million in 2015. Table 1 shows the forecast of the vehicle market in China; the statistical data are from the China Automotive Technology and Research Center.

caption.p: Forecast of vehicles in China.

sec.p: A sharp increase in ELVs presents a grim challenge to the ELV recycling industry in China, as China has not yet established a mature ELV recycling system. Currently, the recycling process of ELVs in China consists of the following steps: end-users apply for ‘Proof of Motor Vehicle Scrap’ from the Agency for Public Security Management. Then, the end-users sell their vehicles to ELV recycling companies certified by the Ministry of Science and Technology, P.R. China. The ‘Proof of ELVs Recycling’ is issued by these recycling companies. Finally, end-users cancel their vehicle registrations with the ‘Proof of ELVs Recycling’ in the Agency for Public Security Management. ELV recycling companies are engaged in dismantling, and in China, no dismantling companies are independent. Decree No. 307 of the State Council, ‘Management Measures on Take-back of Scrapped Automobiles,’ requires that the ‘five supervised assemblies of vehicle’ including the engine, power transmission box, steering, axle and chassis should be destroyed and recycled as metal materials (Chen and Zhang, 2009; State Council Decree [China] No. 307, 2001). Therefore, vehicle bodies and ‘five supervised assemblies of vehicle’ are recycled as metal materials and are sold to steel plants. Some parts, not included in the ‘five supervised assemblies of vehicle,’ are reused or remanufactured.

Recycling companies evidently play a leading role in the ELV system in China. Car manufacturers in China are seldom involved in recycling scrap cars, and they rarely provide dismantling information for recycling companies. In addition, no professional shredding plants exist. Figure 1 shows the current state of the ELV recycling system in China.

caption.p: ELV recycling system in China.

sec.p: Given the rapid development of electronic information technology, the use of electronic components in vehicles has dramatically increased. Electronic control units (ECUs) control almost all vehicle functions (Wuhlegemuth and Hofmann, 1998). According to the statistics of Bayerische Motoren Werke (BMW) AG, the cost of automotive electronic components has exceeded the cost of vehicles by more than 30%. Some luxury cars have 48 microcomputers, and the electronic components account for more than 50% of their cost. Thus, the volume of used automotive electronic control components in China is expected to soar in the next few years.

The used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China has yet to take shape because of a lack of supporting technology and profitable models. Most used automotive electronic control components are scrapped together with vehicle bodies and the ‘five supervised assemblies of vehicle’ for material recycling. A small number of them are sold to maintenance service companies that only rely on visual observation and experience to determine whether these materials can be reused. This kind of inspection is highly risky because damage to some parts cannot be detected by the naked eye. These damaged parts, if reused, may lead to failure and cause accidents.
The current situation of the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry harms social development.

list-item.p: This recycling model causes serious environmental pollution and resource wastage.

Toxic heavy metals, such as Au, Pt, Pb, Ag, Cu, etc., are present in the printed circuit boards (PCBs) of ECUs. The main component of solder is Sn-Pb alloy, which is the main source of Pb pollution coming from ELVs. Pb contamination and poisoning comprise one of the most serious problems that contribute to environmental pollution, gravely endangering human health. The recycling of PCBs is an important contributor to the prevention of heavy metal contamination, particularly Cd, Pb and Ni.

At present, more than 99% of automotive ECUs in China are imported from foreign automotive part suppliers, such as Delphi, Motorola, Bosch, etc. The research and development of ECUs as high-technology products with independent intellectual property rights has not yet achieved a major breakthrough in China. The automotive electronic control components recycling industry promotes sustainable development, and the added technological value can allow for reasonable reuse of related products. The practical experiences of the United States, Japan and Europe confirm that this recycling industry is feasible and can result in considerable technological benefits.
The illegal circulation and use of used automotive electronic control components pose a security risk to automobile users.

Used automotive electronic control components can be reused according to Decree No. 307 of the State Council, ‘Management Measures on Take-back of Scrapped Automobiles.’ However, their reuse is completely determined by the market without quality inspection because the quality standards for reused parts have not been developed. The lack of quality standards results in the dangerous market entry of a large number of used automotive electronic control components that are defective.

Therefore, the used electronic control components recycling industry in China must be immediately developed. Firstly, all practitioners in this particular industry should work hard to overcome difficult problems relating to technology quickly. Secondly, the successful experience of the United States, the European Union and Japan in this industry is worth learning from.

The present study aims to explore development strategies for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China. Based on the ‘strengths, weaknesses/limitations, opportunities and threats’ (SWOT) method, the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities and threats of this industry are analysed and studied. The internal factor evaluation (IFE) matrix and the external factor evaluation (EFE) matrix are used to evaluate the internal and external factors of this recycling industry. The results of the analysis indicate that this industry in China has great potential for development. Finally, the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry, which is led by automotive manufacturers, is set up in accordance with the actual conditions in China. Members of the industry and relevant development strategies are defined.

sec.title: Materials and methods
sec.p: At present, 502 ELV recycling and dismantling companies operate in China. The technical levels of these companies are very different. Most of them are small, and the low level of their technological capabilities does not meet the environmental protection requirements. Secondary environmental pollution is still more serious during the course of dismantling ELVs. Based on this industry background, the Alliance of Auto Recovery Technology Innovation (AARTI) was established in Changchun City, Jilin Province of China on 15 July 2010. The AARTI now consists of 26 members, including six major automobile groups, namely, China First Automobile Works, Dongfeng Automobile Co., Ltd., Beijing Automotive Industry Holding Co., Ltd., Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation (Group), Chongqing Changan Automobile Industry Co., Ltd. and Guangzhou Automobile Group Co., Ltd. The alliance aims to improve the core competitiveness of the automobile industry of China. It is also dedicated to the research and development of general technology for the automobile product recycling industry to promote the industry’s technological progress in energy conservation, emission reduction and comprehensive utilization of waste resources.

The AARTI published the technology roadmap of China for the automobile product recycling industry in 2011. This technology roadmap analyses China’s goal for the rate of recycling of automobile products for the year 2020 (Figure 2).

caption.p: China’s goal for the rate of recycling of automobile products for the year 2020.

sec.p: In 2010, the AARTI organised the ‘3rd Asian Auto Environmental Forum’ (3rd AAEF). The AAEF is organized annually in one of the following four countries: China, Japan, Korea and India. University scholars, automotive manufacturers, ELV recycling and dismantling experts, remanufacturing experts, crushing and material sorting experts, governmental officials as well as technology and industry alliance experts from these four countries make presentations and participate in round table discussions. The communication and cooperation mechanism of the AAEF is developed to promote the conservation of natural resources, the reduction of environmental impact, and the undertaking of international responsibility. The 3rd AAEF deeply influenced the sustainable manufacturing of auto products in the context of international collaboration and cooperation. In this forum, the representatives from Japan, Korea, and India introduced the situation of ELV recycling in their respective countries. The differences in the situation of ELV recycling between China and the three participating countries was analysed and compared. Moreover, the SWOT of the ELV recycling industry in China was analysed. Meanwhile, the participating countries affirmed the correctness and applicability of the model in this study.

In 2011, the AARTI organised the ‘2011 International Auto Recycling & Remanufacture Forum Announcement’. One important issue tackled in the forum, which will be held annually, was the business model and technology innovation intended for the promotion of the automotive products recycling industry in China as one of the emerging industries of strategic importance. The forum invited governmental officials, scholars and managers to give speeches and organize panel discussions as well as exhibitions to promote the internationalization, marketability and sustainable development of the automotive products recycling and remanufacturing industry in China. In this forum, many experts analysed the SWOT of the ELV recycling industry in China. These experts included officials from the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, P.R. China, the President of China National Resources Recycling Association, representatives of the AARTI, experts from the Environmental Management and Recycling, representatives of the BMW Group, the Manager of LKQ Corporation, the Managing Director of SiCon GmbH, the Secretary General of AARTI, the Vice President of China Machinery Industry Federation, officials from the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology, P.R. China, experts from Suzhou 3R Auto Recycling Technology Co., Ltd., the General Manager of Shanghai Bestech Machinery Technology Co., Ltd., the Engineer-in-Chief of Beijing Xianglong Borui Auto Service (Group) Co., Ltd. and the Manager of Shanghai Eastern China Vehicle Dismantling Co., Ltd.

All these top-level scholars and experts, numbering to over 100, analysed the SWOT of the ELV recycling industry in China. They agreed with the results of the analysis presented in the present study. As in the 3rd AAEF, the participants in the forum affirmed the correctness and applicability of the model in this study.

The SWOT analysis identifies the strengths, weaknesses and core competencies of a company or an industry based on internal and external conditions (Chang and Huang, 2006). SWOT is an acronym for ‘strength (S), weakness (W), opportunity (O), and threat (T)’, where S and W represent internal factors, and O and T represent external factors. S and W are referred to in the analyses of the internal strengths and weaknesses of an object. O and T represent the external advantages and disadvantages, respectively (Terry and Roy, 1997).

The EFE matrix is a strategic management tool used to determine whether an industry is able to take advantage of existing opportunities effectively while minimising external threats. The EFE analysis helps formulate new strategies based on the existing position of an industry. The IFE matrix is a strategic management tool for auditing or evaluating the major strengths and weaknesses in the functional areas of an industry (Moharamnejad et al., 2010).

In the current study, the weight of each factor is determined based on the analytic hierarchy process (AHP) method (Thomas, 2005; Thomas and Luis, 1990). The AHP is a multi-objective or multi-criteria measurement that helps solve complicated decision problems by structuring the problems, identifying decision-making factors, measuring the importance of the factors, and synthesising all decision-making factors.

sec.title: Establishment of the hierarchy
sec.p: The target layer aims to formulate the model of the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China. The content of the guideline layer includes the opportunities and challenges of the industry and various key factors that are included in the program layer.

sec.title: Establishment of pairwise comparison matrix A
sec.p: The elements aij of a judgment matrix A were established by comparing the relative importance of the elements in the current level with the upper level. The numbers 1 to 9 were used to indicate the importance of an element. In the 1 to 9 scale method, the value of aij was decided based on the relative importance between targets i and j. The rules are shown in Table 2.

caption.p: The value of aij.

tr.td: i and j have the same importance
j is more important than i
j is obviously more important than i
j is strongly more important than i
j is extremely more important than i
If the ratio of importance in the elements i and j is aij, then the ratio of importance of the element j and i is aji = 1/aij

sec.p: Based on Table 2, the pairwise comparison matrix A can be obtained as follows:
If aij is regarded as approximately the weight ratio of i and j, aij = wi/wj, then the pairwise comparison matrix A can be expressed as follows:

sec.title: Calculation of key factor weight
sec.p: The weight can be calculated based on the pairwise comparison matrix A (James, 1990). In the current study, the root method was used to calculate the weight w as follows:

The total weighted score can be calculated by adding the weights to various opportunities and threats. If the score is greater than 2.5, the industry has a healthy external environment (David, 1998, 2001). Similar to that in the EFE matrix analysis, if the IFE matrix scores are greater than 2.5, the industry has a healthy internal environment.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p: The SWOT of China’s used automotive electronic control components recycling industry are analysed as follows:

list-item.p: Huge quantity of used automotive electronic control components: the abundance of automotive electronic control components indicates sufficient raw materials for the recycling industry, which is a positive factor. However, serious environmental pollution will occur if these components are not treated reasonably (Chen, 2005).

Advantageous labour cost: in China, most used automotive electronic control components are manually dismantled in ELV recycling companies, which is a task that requires extensive labour. The low labour cost in China is a significant advantage for the development of this recycling industry.

Integration and cooperation within the industry: the AARTI relies on the cooperation between industries, universities and research institutes, and is dedicated to the development of key technologies for the market-oriented recycling industry. It is also focused on promoting the development of the recycling industry in general. Integration and coordination within the industry will be advantageous for industry development.
High value added for used automotive electronic control components.
Weak recycling infrastructure: most regions in China have weak recycling infrastructures (Chen and Zhang, 2009).
Non-establishment of a recycling responsibility system for used automotive electronic control components.
Unreasonable distribution of resources within the industry (Zhao and Chen, 2011).
Impedance of industry development caused by environmental pollution.

Unitary and low value-added recycling treatment method: in China, used automotive electronic control components are smashed into pieces together with the vehicles for material recycling or are discarded carelessly.

Policy support for ELV recycling: the legal system of ELV recycling in China consists of four parts: automotive recycling policy; policies, certification rules and technical specifications of the green design of automotive products; policies and technical specifications of recycling and dismantling of ELVs; and policies and technical specifications of automotive parts remanufacturing. All these policies are shown in Table 3.
Huge demand in the market.
Macroeconomic environment conducive to industry progress.
Social requirements related to environmental protection and resource recycling.

caption.p: The legal system of ELV recycling in China.

tr.td: Automotive industry restructuring and revitalisation plan
Technical policy for the recovery of automotive products

tr.th: Policies, certification rules and technical specifications of the green design of automotive products

tr.td: Recoverability of automotive products and management practices of disabled/restricted substances
Implementation of mandatory rules for motor vehicles
Material identification and marking of automotive plastic, rubber and thermoplastic elastomer parts

tr.th: Policies and technical specifications of recycling and dismantling of ELVs

tr.td: Management regulations for the take-back and dismantling of ELVs
Interim measures for ELV scrapped subsidies
Development of recycling scrapped automobiles dismantling companies to inform the pilot demonstration project
Technical specifications for the ELV recycling and dismantling enterprise
Environmental protection technical specifications for the disassembly of ELVs

tr.th: Policies and technical specifications of automotive parts remanufacturing

tr.td: Administrative measures for pilot remanufacturing of automobile parts and assemblies
Notice of deepening of remanufacturing pilot
Notice of management and protection of enabling and strengthening the sign of automobile remanufacturing parts
Technology requirements for the remanufacturing of spark and compression ignition engines

list-item.p: Bottleneck in the test technologies of used automotive electronic control components.
Lack of market drive within the industry.
Inadequate construction of green design and manufacturing systems within associated industries.
Uncertain implementation of policies.

sec.title: SWOT matrix for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry
sec.p: The SWOT matrix for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry is presented in Table 4. The external factors that affect the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China are identified in Table 5 (Chen and Zhang, 2009; Wang and Chen, 2011).

S4 High value added for used automotive electronic control components

W5 Unitary and low value-added recycling treatment method

T1 Bottleneck in the test technologies of used automotive electronic control components
O2 Huge demand in the market

O3 Macroeconomic environment conducive to industry progress
T3 Inadequate construction of green design and manufacturing systems within associated industries

sec.title: Determination of the weight of each external factor
sec.p: Calculated results are listed in Tables 6, 7 and 8.

caption.p: Pairwise comparison matrix of opportunities and threats.
Pairwise comparison matrix of opportunities.
Pairwise comparison matrix of threats.

sec.title: Scores of each external factor
sec.p: Factors are assessed based on the response efficiency of key factors to the current industrial strategies. The scores range from 1 to 4. A score of ‘4’ represents an excellent response; ‘3’ represents a response better than the average level; ‘2’ represents the average response level; ‘1’ represents a poor response. The scores reflect the effectiveness of the current strategies employed in the recycling industry, and the results are shown in Table 9.

caption.p: Scores of opportunities and threats.

tr.td: C1 Policy support for ELV recycling
C2 Huge demand in the market
C3 Macroeconomic environment conducive to industry progress
C4 Social requirements related to environmental protection and resource recycling
D1 Bottleneck in the test technologies of used automotive electronic control components
D2 Lack of market drive within the industry
D3 Inadequate construction of green design and manufacturing system within associated industries

sec.p: The EFE matrix is shown in Table 10.

caption.p: EFE matrix of the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China.

tr.td: C1 Policy support for ELV recycling

C4 Social requirements related to environmental protection and resource recycling
D1 Bottleneck in the test technologies of used automotive electronic control components
D2 Lack of market drive within the industry
D3 Inadequate construction of green design and manufacturing systems within associated industries

fn.p: The total weighted score in the EFE matrix was 3.16 points, which was greater than 2.5. Thus, the industry responds well to the external environment.

sec.p: Table 11 shows the internal factors of the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry.

G3 Unreasonable distribution of resources within the industry

sec.p: The weight of each internal factor can be obtained using the same calculation method, as shown in Tables 12, 13 and 14.

sec.p: Table 15 shows the score of each internal factor.

sec.title: Establishment of the IFE matrix
sec.p: The IFE matrix is shown in Table 16.

caption.p: IFE matrix of the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China.

tr.td: F1 Huge quantity of used automotive electronic control components
F3 Integration and cooperation within the industry
F4 High value added of used automotive electronic control components
G2 Non-establishment recycling responsibility for used automotive electronic control components
G3 Unreasonable distribution of resources within the industry
G4 Impedance of industry development caused by environmental pollution
G5 Unitary and low value-added recycling treatment method

sec.p: The total weighted score in the IFE matrix was 3.10 points, which was greater than 2.5. Thus, the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China takes advantage of the current situation. The advantage factors are stronger than the disadvantage factors.

The EFE matrix and the IFE matrix analyses obtained scores of 3.16 and 3.10, respectively. These scores indicate that the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China responds well to the external and internal environment. The industry internal advantage factors are stronger than the disadvantage factors. Therefore, the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China should adopt a positive growth strategy (Figure 3).

caption.p: The positive development strategy for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China.

sec.p: Automotive manufacturers, who have the advantage of technology, capital, human resources, etc., play a leading role in the extended producer responsibility (EPR) system. As these manufacturers are the main driving forces behind the automotive electronic control components recycling industry, they are expected to lead the industry. However, recycling companies, and not automotive manufacturers, play a leading role in the ELV system in China. The automotive manufacturers are rarely involved in recycling ELVs, and they seldom provide dismantling information for recycling companies. An industry led by automotive manufacturers must be established to develop this industry immediately.
After identifying the industry members, the development strategies for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China has been obtained, as shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Development strategies for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China.

sec.p: After identifying the industry SWOT and the industry members, the development strategies for the used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China was formulated, with automotive manufacturers set up as industry leaders.

In the formulation of the development strategies, the automotive manufacturers were set up as leaders. Hence, the EPR in recycling should be implemented (Chen et al., 2009; Wang and Chen, 2011; Wiesmeth and Dennis, 2011; Wilts et al., 2011). The organisations in this industry should promote an industry standard and a system. An industrial alliance must be established to promote internal and external cooperation within the industry. A series of policies should be introduced to regulate the industry environment. The construction of infrastructure facilities and recycling channels should be strengthened, and the external technical and financial resources should be utilized.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: China has not yet established a mature ELV recycling system, which is presently being led by recycling companies. Automotive manufacturers in China are rarely involved in recycling ELVs, and they seldom provide dismantling information for recycling companies. In addition, no professional shredding plant exists. The used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China has yet to take shape because of the lack of supporting technology and profitable models. Most used automotive electronic control components are scrapped together with vehicle bodies and the ‘five supervised assemblies of vehicle’ for material recycling. The formulation of development strategies for this particular recycling industry must be based on the actual conditions of China. The used automotive electronic control components recycling industry in China is analysed using the SWOT method. The analysis results show that this recycling industry responds well to the external and internal environment. Therefore, this recycling industry should adopt a positive growth strategy. After identifying the industry members, development strategies are formulated, with automotive manufacturers set up as industry leaders.
Alongside the technological, economic, and social development, the recycling development strategies will be constantly updated, and such improvements will be the focus of future research.
